p: A growing number of PSE studies have been undertaken for key populations over the past decade [ 18, 20]. Despite this, there are still many countries where PSE for key populations are inaccurate, incomplete, or missing [ 20, 21]. A review assessing PSE for key populations among low and middle-income countries revealed that out of 54 countries on the African continent, less than half have published size estimation data for any key population, and of those with existing PSE, about half are considered to have nationally adequate estimates [ 20]. Inaccurate and incomplete data are particularly common in countries where study participants may be at risk of arrest due to punitive laws criminalizing sex work, drug use, or non-heteronormative sexual practices [ 9]. Various studies, some in tandem with size estimation exercises, have documented a gap between the burden of HIV in key populations and the coverage of HIV services in these populations in several sub-Saharan African countries [ 13, 22].
